title: ASL Resources
text:
What are these Resources About?
These are educational, fun, or interesting resources on ASL, Deaf culture and history, and other sign languages. Sources marked with a üçí emoji haven‚Äôt been looked at, but they‚Äôre here cuz I thought they seemed useful.
Note to self: remember that the best teacher is a Deaf instructor or tutor. These resources help with learning but are insufficient for getting a thorough understanding of sign languages or Deaf culture.

title: ASL Resources
text:
Deaf Culture & History

Deaf Artists. By RIT NTID.

Lots of info on Deaf artists and art.

Deaf Power. By Christine Sun Kim and Ravi Vasavan, amongst others.

Resources and info from a Deaf power perspective. There is some ASL info, too.

Introduction to American Deaf Culture. First edition. By Thomas K. Holcomb. Published 2012.

I like the book a lot. It reads like a mix between a textbook and a casual account.
Has a companion website.

Meeting and Interacting with Deaf People. By Belinda G. Vicars.

How to interact at Deaf events without seeming like a twat.

Seeing Language in Sign: The Work of William C. Stokoe. By Jane Maher. Published 1996.

Part Stokoe biography and part narrative history, with a focus on Stokoe‚Äôs work on ASL linguistics and the negative reception around it.
Stokoe talks about learning systems theory in 1957. Way earlier than I thought systems theory originated.

Signing Black in America. By the Language & Life Project.

Documentary about Black ASL.

title: ASL Resources
text:
Dictionaries

American Sign Language Handshape Dictionary. By Richard A. Tennant and Marianne Gluszak Brown, and drawings by Valerie Nelson-Metlay.

Nice reverse dictionary, though kinda outdated. Helped me find INTERNET.

ASL Core. By RIT NTID.

Suggested signs for academic + technical topics.

ASL University, also known as Lifeprint. By William G. Vicars.

ASL-English dictionary with explanations of etymology and suggestions for how to memorize signs. Breaks the handshapes down which I find super useful.
Offers an entire ASL curriculum, which is incredible.
I think this was one of the first online ASL resources ever. That‚Äôs really cool.

Handspeak. By Jolanta Lapiak.

Great ASL-English dictionary ‚Äî arguably the best.
Contains an extraordinary reverse dictionary. As far as I can tell, it‚Äôs the only one online. Some signs in the main dictionary are missing in the reverse dictionary.
Has tutorials on grammar and conjunctions and stuff.

Signing Savvy. By a large team.

Useful for finding sociolinguistic or phonological variations of different signs.
I mostly use this to find signs that I‚Äôve failed to find elsewhere.

Spread the Sign. By Thomas Lydell.

Translations for multiple sign languages. Pretty neat, though not super comprehensive.
They have sentences, too.

The Gallaudet Dictionary of American Sign Language. By GU editors and illustrators. Published 2005.

Not an exceptional dictionary. Mostly cuz it‚Äôs so hard to search and pics fail to capture what videos can.
Probably best used to remind me what signs look like. But definitely not for learning.
The chapter on classifiers is nice, though.

The Gallaudet Children‚Äôs Dictionary of American Sign Language. By GU editors and illustrators. Published 2014. üçí

Looks similar to the adult dictionary, but it‚Äôs more colorful, which I like. üåà
Has a companion website.

title: ASL Resources
text:
Linguistics

Books

Grammar, Gesture, and Meaning in American Sign Language. By Scott K. Liddell. Published 2003.

I haven‚Äôt read too far into this book. It‚Äôs a lil beyond my understanding. üòÖ

Linguistics of American Sign Language: An Introduction. Third edition. By Clayton Valli and Ceil Lucas. Published 2000.

I tried to use this book to learn ASL grammar. Not successful.
On the 5th edition (2011) now, but I‚Äôve only read the 3rd.
5e has a list of Youtube videos in lieu of a DVD.

Sign Languages of the World: A Comparative Handbook. Edited by Julie Bakken Jepsen, Goedele De Clerck, Sam Lutalo-Kiingi, and William B. McGregor. Published 2015.

I‚Äôve only read the chapter on Inuit Uukturausingit (IUR or Inuit Sign Language).
No chapter on Hawaii Sign Language, though it is mentioned.

Sign Languages: Structures and Contexts. By Joseph C. Hill, Diane C. Lillo-Martin and Sandra K. Wood. Published 2019.

The first ASL book I read! Turns out that studying linguistics is not the best way to learn a language.
Really good book. Some important things I learned:

Sign languages (like all natural languages) consist of meaningless parts.
There is a specific set of meaningless parts and those parts combine only in certain ways.
In signs that use two hands, either the sign is symmetrical or the non-dominant hand is still. CAT and SALT are respective examples.





Studies

ASL-Lex. By Naomi Caselli and others.

2,723 signs are visualized in a network graph. Closeness is correlated with phonological relatedness.1 Node size is correlated with sign frequency.
It would be nice to also have a graph focused on semantic relatedness. But that‚Äôs harder.
Their 2017 paper says the following:
‚ÄúFor example, signs like PANTS, DRESS, and SKIRT are all fairly iconic and are produced with relatively common sub-lexical properties: the locations are all on the body (depicting where the clothes are worn), and recruit all four fingers fully extended.‚Äù

How the Alphabet Came to Be Used in a Sign Language. By Carol Padden and Darline Clark Gunsauls. Published 2003.

Very cool! Mentions that ASL uses a lot of fingerspelling + suggests some reasons why.
Most fingerspelled words are nouns.

title: ASL Resources
text:
ASL Textbooks

American Sign Language: A Teacher‚Äôs Resource Text On Grammar and Culture. By Charlotte Baker and Dennis Cokely. Published 1980.

Probably my favorite ASL book so far.
From 1980, so it‚Äôs old. I think most of the stuff is still good. But I‚Äôm not qualified to say.
ASL was recognized as a natural language only in 1960, so there‚Äôs a lot of ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt understand this yet.‚Äù I wish there were an updated version.

Barron‚Äôs E-Z American Sign Language. Third edition. By David Stewart, Elizabeth Stewart, Lisa Dimling, and Jessalyn Little. Published 2011.

This is okay. It‚Äôs teaching me new words. Not sure the grammar stuff is super helpful, though.

Sign-Me-Fine. By Laura Greene and Eva Barash Dicker. Published 1990.

ASL grammar book for kids middle school‚Äìaged and older.
Not very good, unfortunately. Don‚Äôt think I understand ASL grammar more after reading this.

The ASL App. By various Deaf signers.

Short video lessons on ASL. Mostly vocabulary.
This helped me with the numbers beyond 99.

Other ASL Pedagogy

Basics

ASL Access. By the ASL Access Board.

Works to ensure that there are free ASL videos available.
Links to a variety of ASL and English resources.

ASL Yes. By Garrett Bose.

Lots of stuff on grammar and structure, including mouth morphemes. Pretty exciting.
Also, there‚Äôs some vocabulary stuff, too.

Gallaudet University‚Äôs ASL Connect.

Very basic ASL organized by topic.
It‚Äôs ASL-pic and not ASL-English.

Handspeak: Fingerspelling Receptive Practice. By Jolanta Lapiak.

As the title. The best fingerspelling reception videos that I‚Äôve found so far.

Lifeprint: Grammar. By William G. Vicars.

On ASL grammar. See also: the myth of STORE I GO, his webpage on ASL sentence structure, and his page on repeated movement in ASL.

Oklahoma School for the Deaf: ASL Classes.

Free online classes for ASL 1 and 2. They‚Äôre asynchronous and consist of videos and written materials.




Specifics

Seven ASL expansion techniques briefly explained.

ASL Rhyme and Rhythmic Songs. By Barb Wifi.

Some notes on ASL rhymes for kids.

Conjunction info:

Brenda Lyons‚Äôs ASL Conjunctions Explained has some suggestions for conjunction memorization.
Jolanta Lapiak‚Äôs Introduction to Conjunctions has a non-exhaustive list of conjunctions and their use.

All about education and teaching ASL and English.
Their videos focus on teaching signs with multiple meanings.

Fingerspelling: Expressive & Receptive Fluency. By Joyce Linden Groode. Published 2004. üçí

Some neat perspectives on ASL use and etymology.

title: Some Notes on Sign Languages
text:
Motivation
I like ASL a lot but I‚Äôm not very good at it. I‚Äôm hoping that keeping these notes will help me learn it better. I also have pencil-and-paper notes, but digital notes like these let me do things like link to videos.
Originally this was a vocab list. I kept forgetting words. Unfortunately I‚Äôm slow and it would take me literal days to transcribe the words and their structure, so I stopped doing that. Probably wasn‚Äôt helping too much anyway. I also read a bunch of books about ASL and wanted to keep track. And I wanted to be able to easily access the document on multiple devices. So: website!
I make a lot of mistakes and I‚Äôm wrong a lot, so hopefully this will help me keep track of those, too.

title: Hawai ªi Sign Language
text:
What is HSL?
Hawaii Sign Language (HSL), or more properly Hawai ªi Sign Language, is a dying sign language indigenous to the Hawaiian archipelago. Through the efforts of Linda Yuen Lambrecht and others, it was finally recognized and documented as a natural language in 2013.
One unique aspect of HSL is its lack of classifiers. I think every other sign language in the world has classifiers. I wonder why HSL doesn‚Äôt have any.

title: ASL Notes
text:
What is This?
Here are my notes on ASL. They‚Äôre super messy, may change a lot, and are almost certainly super duper wrong.

title: ASL Notes
text:
Mistakes I‚Äôve Made
So many. I‚Äôll try to track them here.

Bad Reception
A weak point. I gotta work on my receptive skills. Often I can get the gist, but the specifics are beyond me. This makes it difficult to participate in discussions.
Bill Vicar has some tips on how to get receptive practice.


Missing Signs
Sometimes, when I watch people sign, some signs just drop out of my consciousness and I only realize that the person signed them later. I think this is just a receptive skills thing. Hopefully, more exposure and training will solve this problem.
Similarly, when I sign I may drop words and fail to sign them. I‚Äôm hoping this is also a skill issue, but it may be part of my general difficulty with communication.


Overgeneralization
This is a good one, in the sense that kids go through something similar during language acquisition.
When teaching us how to sign race, Jamil signed SOUTH ASIAN for himself. I wrongly assumed the S-handshape was correct for all cardinal directions. Robert later taught us that north is signed with the N-handshape.


Picture & Book Reliance
Sometimes I sign things incorrectly cuz I look at still pics (or try to figure it out from words) instead of videos. Usually the handshape is right, but I do the movements wrong.


Syntax Not Semantics
This is a bad one, in the sense that this generally only happens to grown-ups who learn a new language.
I mix up words which have similar syntax, like BIRTHDAY and FAVORITE, just cuz a lot of the parameters are the same. This is bad! Like, native English speakers don‚Äôt confused ‚Äúbat‚Äù and ‚Äúcat‚Äù just cuz they sound similar. They mean very different things. BIRTHDAY and FAVORITE mean very different things, too. But I make these mistakes cuz I‚Äôm not a native ASL signer.

title: ASL Notes
text:
Understanding the Parts of ASL
ASL phonology! Signs consist of 5 parts, or parameters:

Handshape: the shape of the hands.
Movement: how your hands move. For example, verbs move once and nouns twice; e.g.¬†EAT and FOOD.
Location: where the hands are.
Palm Orientation: which way your palms are facing.
Non-manual Signals: consist of everything else. Facial expressions, head tilts, body movements, mouth position, and eye gaze. Handspeak has a good explanation of them.

You combine those parts to create a sign. That sign is a morpheme, or a basic unit of meaning. It can either exist by itself or be combined with other signs to generate larger signs. For example, TEACH and PERSON combine into TEACHER.
Some specifics:

Movement
Signing fast can be used to mean ‚Äúvery.‚Äù For example: signing SLOW quickly means ‚Äúvery slow.‚Äù (So does signing it slowly. So maybe not the best example.)
Making your movements bigger when signing can imply largeness. For example: signing FAMILY while making a very large circle means ‚Äúbig family.‚Äù


Location
When fingerspelling, location influences loudness. Signing around shoulder height is typical. Signing above the shoulder is shouting, and signing below it is whispering.

title: ASL Notes
text:
Doing Things with Signs
Moving on from the parts themselves to sentences, word order, and just doing stuff that isn‚Äôt just signing one word.

Conjunctions
Remember that a conjunction binds two propositions together. ASL has conjunctions similar to English‚Äôs and even more. In ASL, when signing a conjunction, raise yr eyebrows.
Let‚Äôs see. There‚Äôs a bunch:

There‚Äôs the rhetorical questions. These are used often. Maybe too often.

There‚Äôs WHO, WHAT, WHERE, WHEN, WHY, and HOW. Those are straightforward.
Also REASON. And FOR-FOR, though I‚Äôm not sure when to use FOR-FOR versus FOR WHAT.

IF or SUPPOSE. Begin with SUPPOSE and then pause between the propositions.
Don‚Äôt use AND. Instead, use PLUS. Or, depending on the context, use ADD, ALSO, BOTH, WITH, or simply index.
There are also some conjunctions that aren‚Äôt used in English. I noticed that I don‚Äôt really use them spontaneously, nor do my classmates. Not quite sure how to resolve that. These include:

WRONG: suddenly, without warning
HAPPEN: just learned, just like that
DISCOVER: find out, realized
FRUSTRATED: being stopped from
HIT: unexpectedly, coincidence


Jolanta Lapiak has written about conjunctions.


Indexing
You can do two things with indexing:

Use it to refer to one or more present x, y, ... z. Like a person or an object.
Use it to refer to one or more absent or hypothetical x, y, ... z.

The first thing is easy. The second thing I‚Äôm not so good at. Sign-Me-Fine talked about it. They suggested a signer index all x, y, ... z and then use directional verbs between them. Barron‚Äôs E-Z American Sign Language instead suggests indexing when needed, which seems more natural to me.


YOU ‚Ä¶ YOU?
That expresses the concept of ‚Äúare‚Äù. It‚Äôs a form of emphasis or formality or clarity.

title: ASL Notes
text:
Word Order
Word order is hard! Word order is so hard that I‚Äôve separated it from the Doing Things with Signs section, which overlaps a lot with this section.
I‚Äôm not a native signer, which means I don‚Äôt have an intuitive sense of ASL grammar and whether a sequence of signs seems right or not. This leads to sloppy, confused, and disordered signing.

Theoretical Knowledge
Sign Languages: Structures and Contexts mentions that ASL is relatively plastic, and that only VSO is illegal.
William G. Vicars calls SVO the most basic (or common) order in ASL. He also mentions that topicalization shouldn‚Äôt be overused and gives ‚ÄúSTORE I GO‚Äù as an example. Instead, ‚ÄúI GO STORE‚Äù is more common, which matches the English order of ‚ÄúI go to the store.‚Äù Garrett Bose agrees.
Which is to say: ASL can be shaped like English and maybe even often is. But to use the shape of English as our guide is a mistake. That makes expressing ASL awfully tricky. I haven‚Äôt figured it out yet.


Examples
Let‚Äôs look at some English‚Äìglossed ASL examples.

I do not earn enough money ‚Äî I EARN MONEY NOT ENOUGH.

Both are SVO.
The difference between them is where ‚Äúnot‚Äù is. In ASL, NOT is modifying ENOUGH. In English, ‚Äúnot‚Äù is modifying ‚Äúearn enough.‚Äù
What‚Äôs the fancy linguistic term for the difference? Why does it matter?

I have seen this movie three times ‚Äî THIS MOVIE I FINISH WATCH THREE-TIMES.

SVO versus OSV, I think.
‚Äúhave‚Äù and FINISH are both modifying ‚Äúseen‚Äù and WATCH, respectively. So that‚Äôs the same.

I will be back soon ‚Äî BACK SOON WILL.

SVO versus OV. This is a pretty big difference. Not sure what to think of it.
